Award.AwardTitle: Mechanistic Studies of Halenium-Alkene Additions for Chemical Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award, funded by the Chemistry Division Chemical Catalysis program in the Division of Chemistry to Professor Babak Borhan at Michigan State University, enables mechanistic analysis and discovery of asymmetric halofunctionalizations. By probing the mechanistic nuances of these processes, this research will expedite design and discovery of new halogenation reactions, improved catalysts, and efficient routes to complex structures. The project's interdisciplinary combination of organic syntheses, spectroscopic techniques, isotopic analyses, and quantum chemical models offers an excellent opportunity for doctoral students to be trained at the interface of analytical, organic, and physical chemistry. Working with PIs of very different backgrounds, the chemistry graduate, undergraduate (UG), and summer high school (HS) students who perform the research learn critical thinking and communications skills, besides the multiple lab techniques they must master.

Professor Borhan's discovery that organocatalyst (DHQD)2PHAL promotes chiral delivery of halogens to alkenes and related substrates opens the door to reactions analogous in generality and utility to recent asymmetric epoxidations, dihydroxylations, and hydrogenations, landmark tools of organic synthesis. These novel stereocontrolled halocyclizations give rapid access to complex structures of biological and pharmaceutical importance. Mechanistic studies employ kinetic analyses; solvent effect surveys; isotopic labeling both to trace stereochemistry and to identify key rate- and product-determining steps via kinetic isotope effects; design and synthesis of electronically adjustable substrates and halogenating agents; multinuclear and multidimensional NMR techniques to probe molecular interactions; and detailed quantum chemical simulations to guide and interpret experiments. Molecular modeling and mechanistic explorations also benefit from the involvement of Professor James Jackson, a physical organic chemist with substantial experience in computational, catalytic, and green chemistry areas, who serves as a Co-PI on this grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic molecules are central to everyday life, with roles as pharmaceuticals and bioactive agents, chemical feedstocks for industrial applications, flavors and fragrances, materials, sensors, dyes and displays, energy capture and conversion, etc.  All but the simplest organic compounds exhibit chirality, otherwise known as handedness. In biological molecules, this handedness is key, sometimes differentiating a nutrient from a neurotoxin. Fundamental to the chemist's practices is the ability to controllably make such handed organic molecules. For nearly a hundred years, the chemistry to introduce halogens (chlorine, bromine, and iodine) to molecules that have an unsaturation (double bond) was thought to be understood.  However, with the funds secured in this NSF grant, a new, closer look at this transformation found that the reaction path was often more defined, and therefore more controllable than prviously thought.  As in the macroscopic world, understanding mechanisms--how reactions work--enables researchers to optimize and refine them, and potentially to invent brand new pathways.  By devising a quantitative scale to classify the tendency for a molecule to react with a halogen (the halenium affinity scale), we created a tool that chemists can use to predict reactivity between molecules and halogen sources. In the process, we also identified the principles to go beyond empirical searches to the purposeful design of reactions leading to a specific desired handed form, or "stereoisomer."

As important as the scientific progress has been, the collaborations among the graduate and undergraduate students engaged in the research have also been key to the success of this project.  The team, almost exactly 50:50 women and men, had amazing energy, adaptability, and esprit de corps. Their achievement of the above breakthroughs reflected not only their work ethic, but also their intense attention to scientific detail and their education in the scientific method.  Solving the problems at hand required a multidisciplinary approach, which challenged all participants to hone their skills and versatility with multiple chemical tools.  Getting the data was only one part of the effort. Experimental replication, critical data analysis, and effective communication (both listening and talking) in the development of hypotheses and proposals for further work are skills essential for any good scientist.  As interpretations solidified, students were then charged with assembling manuscripts. Writing the first scientific paper is a daunting challenge for anyone.  It would be easier and much more efficient for the PIs to write the paper, but the experience of pulling together lines of reasoning to make convincing, rational arguments leading to well-defined conclusions is an essential part of becoming a scientist. Also paramount are the small points; every detail matters in reporting and explaining chemistry, from font sizes and tense matching, to formatting and labeling of graphics, footnotes, calculations and spectra. Ultimately, this practical focus on details, accuracy, and critical thinking is an asset to any student's growth and future opportunities, no matter where their career paths may lead. It is a point of pride that as these well-equipped students have graduated, whether at the bachelors or doctorate levels, they have essentially all moved on to excellent employment opportunities where they quickly became indispensable to their new teams.
